title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: (See Monastery, vol. i.) From this bridge the Girthgate, a path to the sanctuary of Soutra, runs up the valley of Allan Water, and over the moors to Soutra Ilill.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: To the right are seen the woods of Abbotsford, and to the left " The Pavilion," the mansion of Lord Somerville, situated on the banks of the Allan Water.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: You must know, that in Ramsay's Tea-table, tvliere the modern song first appeared, the ancient name of the tune, Allan says, is "Allan Water," or "My love Annie's very bonnie."

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: I walked out yesterday evening with a volume of the Museum in my hand, when turning up " Allan Water," " What numbers shall the muse repeat," &c., as the words appeared to me rather unworthy of so fine an air, and recollecting that it is on your list, I sat and raved under the shade of an old thorn, till I wrote one to suit the measure.

snippet: You must know, that in Kamsay's Tea-table, where the modern song first appeared, the ancient name of the tune, Allan says, is "Allan Water," or "My love Annie's very bonnie."

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: I walked out yesterday evening with a volume of the Museum in my hand, when turning up " Allan Water," " What numbers shall the muse repeat," &c., as the words appeared to me rather unworthy of so fine an air, and recollecting that it is on your list, I sat and raved under the shade of an old thorn, till I wrote one to suit the measure.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: Therewas a pleasant glance, which I caught as we stopped for amoment at Dumblane, of Jessie's child—" Jessie, the Flowerof Dumblane"—I knew her instantly, sitting on the stepsof one of the cottage-doors, barefoot, and playing with herchubby little toes ! Then we passed the Bridge of Allan,over that " Allan Water" so famous in song; and the shadedbanks seemed to be whispering something pleasant from thepastoral days.
